title: P3 Gold (Prusa) - Black Diamond Bowden E3D v5 Hotend.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update 3:
Add module Suport for EndStop MakerBot.
Add module Suport for Sensor Inductive 8, 12, 18mm.
Add suport for frontal Fan 40x40mm.

Update 2: Desing 45mm X-Rods for Prusa i3, P3Steel, Hephestos and more...Please measure the distance between the X-axis rods, if it is different and you would like to use this head, discuss it and adapt the measurements.

Update 1: Desing for Anet A8: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2389014

A New Modular Hotend for P3 Gold, Prusa i3, Prusa i3 Steel and more.

Video Youtube:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PUkOH_597Hg&t=3s

ENG:
+
I present a new head for our PRUSA, designed in style to be functional, simple to assemble and light at the same time as robust.

Among its characteristics:

  • Lightweight, only 183g, and may be lighter if POM plastic bearings are installed and an E3D v6 (shorter would require a revision that is on the way.
  • Narrow, its diamond-shaped design makes you win a few millimeters that always come well and prepares the way for a double Bownden upright (also on the way)
  • Robust, printed only at 20% density gives lightness and robustness to support almost everything;) (I want to do tests for a Dremel 200.
  • BLTouch (Optional), It has a hole designed for the mentioned Autolevel.
    Fan layer (Optional), 40x40mm at the back without losing print surface (depends on your printer configuration).
  • Character, gives our PRUSA an elegant and at the same time serious professional character in the design.

NOTE: This design is designed to use brass inserts, but self-locking nuts can be used without problems as shown in the following pictures:

https://imgur.com/0zVvhrr
https://imgur.com/1n7RGzL
https://imgur.com/NIhw52Y

I hope you like it.

ESP (Original)
*
Les presento un nuevo cabezal para nuestras PRUSA, diseñado con estilo para ser funcional, sencillo de montar y ligero al mismo tiempo que robusto.

Entre sus características:

  • Ligero, solo 183g, y puede ser mas ligero si se instalan rodamientos IGUS de plástico POM y un E3D v6 (al ser mas corto se necesitaría una revisión que esta en camino.
  • Estrecho, su diseño en forma de diamante hace que se ganen unos milímetros que siempre vienen bien y prepara el camino para un Bownden doble en vertical (también en camino)
  • Robusto, impreso solo a 20% de densidad otorga ligereza y robustez para soportarlo casi todo ;) (quiero hacer pruebas para una Dremel 200.
  • BLTouch (Opcional), Dispone de un hueco diseñado a propósito para el Autolevel mencionado.
    Ventilador de capa (Opcional), de 40x40mm en la parte de atrás sin perder superficie de impresión (depende configuración de tu impresora).
  • Carácter, otorga a nuestra PRUSA un elegante y a su vez serio carácter profesional en el diseño.

NOTA: Este diseño esta preparado para usar insertos de latón, pero pueden usarse tuercas autoblocantes sin problemas como muestran las siguientes imágenes:

https://imgur.com/0zVvhrr
https://imgur.com/1n7RGzL
https://imgur.com/NIhw52Y

Espero sea de su agrado.

print_settings.Notes:: Almost same temperatures as PLA

description.text:
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:915435

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=915435

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2um

Infill:

20%

Notes:

primaSELECT PETG box recommended temperatures:
Print temp: 195-235ºc (40ºc difference)
Bed temp: 35-60ºc (On website they say heatbed no required, i use 50-55ºc)

Since this PETG have a lower melt temperature than others this tower is aimed to test filament against temperature to obtain the perfect temperature and features with 5ºC steps.

Since not everybody have Simplify3D, other tools or know to modify gcode, i have added the sliced gcode for Original Prusa MK2 ONLY!!!!!!! Temperature will change at every new cube.

My Review:

After print and analize the model i also inspect using stereo microscope.
Temperatures from 240ºc to 230ºc are to much you can notice the melted cubes and bad detail, 225ºc better than previous but still is a high setting that produce a bad detail and should be avoid.
So we are discarding the four highest temperatures, leaving us with:
[220,215,210,205,200,195]
Now lets jump to lowest temperatures, [195,200,205], 195 produced a good eye quality, but failt at some aspects, the arc is not well defined and as this is the lowest recommened should be avoided, not because of final quality but i also do force test, with two fingers i was able to separate layers on middle of 195, thats not a good thing. 200ºc and 205ºc have a good quality, similar to the 195 but a little better, still they are weak too, i was able to smash them with my fingers, also they risk to not stick well to the bed.
Now leave us only with: [210,215,220], and i must say that should be the real range for a good print with this filament. First i can't break them easly with my finger, even if i put my max force (same for 225-240), if we follow same rule to discard the first 4 temps we end with: [215,220] and i must say under the microscope that are the best settings you can use, from all temperatures this two are the ones with less imperfections and more quality.

Bottom line:
This primaSELECT PETG looks like a easy to print PETG, you can print at 195ºc with good visual quality, but if you can go up to 220ºc you will get the maximum quality of it.
Also they say you not need a heatbed, i haven't test but i use 50 for first layers and 55 for the rest. This is a good thing because you will spare time (heat up 90º at 12v take very time) and also you spare your eletric power. 55ºc much easier to maintain than 90ºc.

My Settings:
(First Layer) - (Other Layers)
Hotend: 215ºc - 220ºc
Bed: 50ºc - 55ºc

Almost same temperatures as PLA

Using the following options:

FontDepth = 0.5
NumberOfBlocks = 10
TowerBase = [15,15,2]
BlockSize = [10,10,10]
DoYouUnderstandYouMustModifyTheGCodeThisMakes = 7
FontFace = 2
fn_override = 0
WallThickness = 1.2
Labels = [240,235,230,225,220,215,210,205,200,195]

TopOfTriangleThickness = 2

print_settings.Notes:: No supports are required for the tracks the way they are set up.  The turret and the body will need some supports.

description.text:
This is (approximately) a 1:100 scale model of a AAV-P7/A1 RAM/RS with EAAK armor. I spent almost 10 months working this model (on and off) in Sketchup and printing prototypes. I lost count of how many of these I printed until I was happy with it, but it's over 25.

Working around AAV's and having a 3d printer, I really wanted a good representative model I could have for my desk or wherever. The models I've found online of AAV's were either highly detailed that couldn't print, or models that could print but had poor (or wrong) details. I was looking for something in the middle, so I used it as an opportunity to learn Sketchup and do it myself.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select V2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

15%

Notes:

No supports are required for the tracks the way they are set up. The turret and the body will need some supports.

The tracks are separate from the body so they can print face up to get more consistent results. Also, if someone just wanted to do a quick spray paint job, it's easier if the tracks are off the vehicle.

For glue, I generally use Loctite Super Glue Ultra Gel Control.

The final drive (sprocket) side of the track goes towards the front of the vehicle. For the turret, I've found that sometimes after it's painted, it's snug enough to stay on without having to be glued.

This model was designed to have as much detail as I could get that would actually show up at that scale. Every prototype print I would learn what looks good on a computer doesn't necessarily show up when you print it. Conversely, I found out that sometimes features had to be exaggerated on the screen to get them to show up right in the print.

Special Thanks

A special thanks to all the Active and Retired 1833's, 2141's, and 1803's who have provided constructive criticism to help me add as much detail as I can that will actually show up when printed. I printed more than 25 of these, and each iteration got better and better because of them.

Now my only problem is they are all going to want their own section of 3d printed tracks...

title: Zentrierständer für Fahrrad-Laufräder / bicycle wheel truing stand

description.text:
GENERAL

This is a centering-stand for bicycles (https://youtu.be/lWbWG2VxNOA). Good ones are very expensive and I thought to help me and others by building one on my own. I'm using the self-centering gears from Catarina Mota (Helical Gears / https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1339). Feel free to improve the Design: https://github.com/VirToReal/Centering-Stand-for-Bicycle/

Its fully customizable with the help of parameters in OpenSCAD. The Thingiverse-Customizer wont work here, because the "gears_helical.scad" must be in the same directory of the "Zentrierstaender.scad". Simply download them or clone from the Git-Hub Link.

CONSTRUCTING

Add the Parameters to fit the size of your wheel. You can be clumsy with that,
because the turquoise colored rods in the OpenScad-Preview are threaded-rods
and can be easily adjusted to your needed distances. Because of that, better
give some more than having to less at the end.

The variable "printmode" help you switch between OpenSCAD-Preview and Printmode.
The Preview shows your Adjustments on the Parameters. The "printmode = true" with
it's following variables will prepare a print-ready layout of your parametered
Structures. The length of each (not printable) Threaded-Rod will be "echoed" in the
OpenSCAD-Console. They can be cut in exact that length.

Following things have to be considered while building:

  • RIM-GRABBER:

  • All other small holes can be drilled up to 4mm for 20mm long M4 Screws to
    assemble the whole Rim-Grabber altogether.

  • You have to pull a shell with the length of 10.15mm inside the two gears
    The Diameter of the shell should match the size of appr. 5-5.9mm, it doesn't
    have to be exact that size, tolerance to the Hole in the Gear is desirable.
    You have to drill up the Hole in the Gears up to appr. 6mm too, because your
    printer won't work that exactly. For Example: I used 2x 3mm² end sleeves which
    fits perfectly.

There must fit a 3mm Screw inside that shell to fix these two gears together
with fewer tolerances. Be sure the screws just fix the shell with the other
two structures (cap/baseplate), not the gears! Some grease will help, too!
The two arms of the Grabber should touch in the center before mounting.
You can rotate them altogether to fix them afterwards. Just be sure they're
in the right teeth of the gear. ITS IMPORTANT THAT THESE GEARS HAVE NO
TOLERANCES TO EACH OTHER.

  • The two big holes are for the Threaded Rods. They're also fixing the "cap"
    on the "baseplate" with the Gears between them.

  • Cut a thread into the two Grabber-Arms for M5-Screws and place some inside
    them. They should look out the structure the same distance. If you failed
    with assembling the Grabber-Arms correctly, you can adjust here.

ALL OTHER PARTS:

  • Not much to consider, just use Nut-Traps if there are one. Washers may prevent
    the plastic from damage. Locknuts on some points may help against self adjusting.
    The OpenSCAD Preview with "printmode = false" may explain everything to you.

USING

Consider following things before start working with this tool:

  • Be sure to tighten the Axis by clamping them in with the two Impeller-Holder.

  • You have to measure in your Rim first before start working on it. You're able
    to rearrange the "Rim-Grabber" on the Threaded Rod for this.

  • If all Threaded Rods are tightened, the whole Structures may move during work
    on your rim, but they'll always move back in they're original position. The
    position will stay the same even after reinserting the rim after removal.

  • You'll detect the wrong position by the sound when the rim touches one of the screws.
    Measuring right at the Rim-Grabber makes it easy to adjust the spokelength. Always Adjust 3 spokes before/after the one with the strongest swing to get a smoother result.
    You're also be able to add a metal-plate to detect runouts of the rim. Just use the
    upper two screws of the Rim-Grabber to mount one.

Printer:

Heavily improved Prusa I3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3 mm Layer with 0.4 mm Nozzle

Infill:

40%

Tinkercad

Here are some bowls and vases based on epicycloids. Epicycloids have been stacked so that the exterior of the bowl forms a portion of an ellipse rotated around the vertical axis. Four bowls are included: epi_bowl_1.stl - small flat bowl with 3 cusps
epi_bowl_2.stl - roughly spherical bowl with 5 cusps
epi_bowl_3.stl - tall bowl with 9 cusps
hypo_bowl_4.stl - tall bowl with no cusps OpenSCAD code, which can construct bowls based on epicycloids and hypocycloids, is included.
Epi_bowl_1.stl needs external support.  The other bowls can be printed directly on the build platform.

description.text:
Barney Rubble, from the Flintstones cartoon show by Hanna-Barbera.

The Flintstones cartoon takes place in a romanticized Stone Age setting, depicting the lives of the Flintstone family and their best friends and neighbors the Rubbles.

Barney was modeled in proportion to my Fred, Wlima and Dino models.
Fred: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1361894
Wilma: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2345526
Dino: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1473207

No supports are required. If you have the proper filament colors, no painting is needed.

The model is 240mm tall.

Enjoy, and I hope you have a "Yaba Daba Do" time printing this!

Printing and assembly tips

title: Small Display Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Small custom display box for LEGO® Minifigures.
This size fit a space available on a TV stand. Feel free to modify size to suit your needs.
Current project file features pieces to make two boxes with two separate shelves per box.
This design can be cut from a single 12" x 24" piece of 1/8" thick wood.

In an updated version I would adjust the width of the overall piece to allow the base plates to fit better. For 25 studs to fit this could be something like a few millimeters.

Be sure to measure your wood! My sheet was actually 23.82" x 11.81"
Base plates used for the design were glued to each shelf (with craft glue - Aleene's Original Tacky Glue) with a total of 25 studs wide and 4 studs deep. Actual base plates used for each shelf:
1x4 (25) (see photos) or 4x6 (4) in alternate option (leaves gap)

In this design 25 studs fit across the shelves snugly. Note that the furthermost studs are not functional (too close to sides). Using any configuration with 24 studs (e.g., 4 of the 4x6 base plates) across can leave a gap at either end of the shelf but characters still fit best with a row of studs left empty (arms bump out too far - see photos). The depth for this project fits 4 studs well. The gap at either side is a matter of preference.

Each shelf holds about 6-7 minifigures (see photos) regardless of the configuration used. The open space between shelves is equal for the top two (about 2.40" or 6.1 cm), but the lower shelf (bottom piece) has less space - the height is 2.20" or 5.6 cm. The top two shelves accommodate the taller characters I have so this works just fine for me :)

Each box is made up of:
back piece (measures: 8" wide x 7.5" tall)
left side (measures: 7.264" tall x 1.264" deep)
right side (measures: 7.264" tall x 1.264" deep)
top piece (measures: 8" wide x 1.264" deep)
bottom piece (measures: 8" wide x 1.264" deep)
shelf (two used - each measures: 7.7362 wide x 1.2992" deep)

NOTE: shelves do protrude slightly, adjust depth to that of the top/bottom piece at 1.264" if that is an issue...but match depth of base plate (in this case the 1.264" depth would work just fine for the 1x4 plate pieces used)

Use http://www.makercase.com/ to generate other boxes. This design started with a basic SVG file created from the website. Shelves were added separately and layout was adjusted to accommodate pieces for two total boxes to be cut from a single sheet of wood. Note that path alignment for files are set for laser cutting efficiency.

Base plates were purchased in exact size/color needed from LEGO® Pick-A-Brick online: https://shop.lego.com/en-US/Pick-a-Brick or hand picked at the Pick-a-Brick wall of a local LEGO® store.

Kept the wood raw instead of painting. Total cost for this project was about $7 worth of pieces (small PAB cup fit these and plenty more) and the wood I had on hand cost around $2 when purchased. That makes the total investment for two custom displays that fit space I had a whopping $9 (or $4.50 each). Definitely a fun project!

Files included are PDF and SVG - lines are set as "hairline" for vector cutting. Delete text or send the job as vector only, otherwise letters/words will be etched as raster. Text is meant to show users the type of piece (L/R are side pieces, T/B are top or bottom and shelves are marked).

STL of 3D model mock up is included for reference (never printed) too. Measurements are identical to those given for laser cut project. Please let me know if you need any other type of file to make your own remix!

description.text: For quite a while I've been searching for a wall hanger suiting my Banjo. The one I have has its pegs on the back of the head and the whole instrument was resting on those pegs when using a standard guitar wall holder. I didn't like the idea so I tried an Ukulele wall holder recently. Now the head fits nicely into the gap between the forks BUT since a Ukulele wall holder is designed for much lighter instruments than my 3.5kg Gretsch I wasn't sure about the holders' stability. A wall console should take the weight. This one supports an openback 11" pot and comes in a standard and filleted version. The other is for a Deering Goodtime OB - this instrument features a special string holder with a screw and nut at the bottom so it needs a notch. Keep on pickin' !

This simple but powerful mini-weapon is capable of shooting matches or toothpicks 20+ feet! It is powered by the spring from an ordinary clothespin. Once printed, simply insert the spring and push the matchstick all the way through the barrel of the gun. It will cock itself. Aim and pull the spring back like a regular trigger. You can carve out the clothespin to shoot the match, but it takes a lot of work and trial and error. It is much easier to print this matchstick gun, since it shoots farther anyway. There are a few designs for clothespin guns already on Thingiverse, but this one has been designed to be the most efficient. It takes only a half hour to print on my printer, with default infill (This may change based on printer type).
Note: It may be small, but this matchstick gun packs a punch, so don't shoot at anyone's face, eyes, or bare skin. Other than that, feel free to use anything as target practice.

This is my take on the HomePod because I cannot wait for it to come out!

I do have two Ultimate UE Boom 1 & 2 speakers so i designed it so they fit inside and I can pretend until xmas that I have one already.

Its designed in 3 components,
-The main body (sorry for the big file but there is a lot of geometry in there to create the -weave as best as i could). I couldnt add more because my computer wouldnt allow me.
-the adapter piece for the boom (base)

  • a top (no it does not have the cool screen on top sadly, but a logo)

Please post it and share how we cant wait to get our hands on this revolutionary new item at the apple store.

ONE MORE THING.....

You need to print it at 110% to make the Boom fit otherwise it wont.
At 100% it would be the exact size as the real deal +/- a vew millimitres.

post a photo when you have printed it.

title: Pepper Spray Gun V2 Remix With Picatinny Rail

description.text:
I fell in love with MechEngineerMike's Pepper Spray Gun, I wanted to make a few variants for people. I have yet to print this, but I am printing his V2 Model.

I added a Picatinny Rail to the top of the gun, it should fit a gun sight. I used mani_60's Picatinny rail for my design. I have not printed it, and do not plan to. I hope you guys do and please tell me if it works. I really think it will.

Enjoy

Must use supports on the 'body' component!
The barrel file should be rotated so that it is 'shooting the printbed'
The two hinges are 1/4" polyethylene tube pressed into the holes."
-MechEngineerMike

description.text:
Hier eine kleine "quick and dirty" Anleitung um den Flashforge Finder mit einem beheizten MK3 Druckbett auszurüsten. Da diese von den Anschlüssen nicht immer gleich sind verzichte ich hier darauf genaue cm Angaben etc. zu machen und beschränke mich auf den Aufbau. Der Ausdruck erfolgt dann auf ein aufgelegt Spiegelfliese die gewechselt werden kann. Das ganze Funktioniert sehr ordentlich und erweitert das Filamentspektrum für den Drucker enorm.

Die benötigten Teil habe ich mit Extrudr´s "Green-Tec" gedruckt damit sie Hitzebeständig sind. Gerade für die Halterungen der Spiegelfliese wichtig. Bedenkt, falls Temperaturen über 110C am Bett erreicht werden sollen kommt Green-Tec an seine Grenzen, dann führt kein weg an HTPLA vorbei (Frustpotential beim Ausbacken, hat mich etliche Nerven gekostet weil die Teile sich minimal verziehen). Für meine Zwecke reichen 80 C am Druckbett aber völlig aus.

Die Teileliste findet Ihr ganz unten.

To Dos und weitere Optimierungen des Druckers:

  • Einfassung des Betts optimieren und besser Isolieren
  • Temperatur Regelung (derzeit noch über verschiedene Netzteile)
  • Kamerahalterung am Druckbett (PI Zero W mit Cam?)
  • Filament Guard umbauen
  • Bauraum isolieren
  • Temperaturüberwachung der Motoren

Bitte denkt daran das ihr euren Drucker beim Umbau Beschädigen könnt. Also bitte alles mit Vorsicht.

Kommentare und Verbesserungsvorschläge Willkommen.

Das Heizbett ist 21,4 x 21,4 cm groß. Daher habe ich eine 2mm Aluminium Platte auf 21,4x22 cm zugeschnitten(22 damit ich hinten noch etwas mehr Spiel für den Halter habe). Danach habe ich den unteren Teil des Original Betts aufgelegt und die Bohrung für die Stellschraube angezeichnet (vorne ist die Bohrung 6cm vom Rand entfernt hinten ist sie mittig auch wenn es nicht so aussieht ). Danach habe ich die gedruckten Halterungen aufgelegt und dafür die Bohrungen angezeichnet. Als letztes wurde das Heizbett vorne bündig angelegt und hierfür die Bohrungen angezeichnet Alu Platte nach dem Bohren und Anschleifen für die Lackierung. Die Platte habe ich mit Ofenrohrlack lackiert. Muss nicht sein aber schadet auch nicht. Jede Halterungen der Oberseite wird ich mit 4 M3 Kreuzschlitz Schrauben versehen. Die Halterungen auf der Unterseite haben Aussparungen für M3 Muttern. Die Muttern einfach in die Haltung drücken und dann das Ganze zusammen schrauben. (Ich habe die Schrauben danach eingekürzt damit sie nachher nicht im Weg sind) Die Abstandshalter für das Heizbett werden Unten mit einer Mutter gesichert. Ich verwende hier Nylon Spacer. Es können auch die Abstandshalter die man von PC-Gehäusen kennt verwendet werden. Allerdings Leiten diese die Wärme besser und heizen damit die Aluplatte mehr auf. Aktuell Teste ich noch aus was die Nylonversion ab kann(Heizbett 90C war bis jetzt ok, hoffe es bleibt auch so). Aluplatte mit fertig montierten Halterungen. Danach werden die Schrauben des Original Druckbetts von Oben eingesetzt und das ganze in den Drucker eingebaut. Am einfachsten geht es wenn die Federn auf der Halterung im Drucker aufgesetzt werden und man dann die Platte drauf setzt. Jetzt muss das Druckbett selbst vorbereitet werden. Hierfür muss es auf die Aluplatte montiert werden (ich wollte meine Anschlüsse auf der Linken Seite also habe ich es so eingebaut :) ). Dann habe ich eine Spiegelfliese auf das Bett gelegt und die Manuelle X-Y Steuerung des Druckers benutzt um die Richtige Position für die Fliese zu finden (etwas fummelig ab geht eigentlich ganz gut). Die Fliese habe ich mit den Selbstklebenden Kork Pads an den Seiten fixiert. Da ich 100 Prozent sicher gehen wollte das es auch wirklich passt habe ich das Bett gelevelt und eine Druck angestoßen der 4 kleine Würfel genau in den Ecken des Bauraums druckt. Final die Kabel anlöten, etwas Kapton Band als "Schutz-Laufflächen" auf das Druckbett kleben und optional den Rest des Betts mit Kork verkleiden (Aussparungen für die Halterung nicht vergessen). Hier nochmal das Bett mit eingesetzter Spiegel-Fliese, komplett mit Kork eingefasst (Schwarz lackiert) und mit den Clip-Halterungen fixiert. (das Gelb an der Fliese ist Kapton Band das ich um die Ecke geklebt habe damit ich das Heizbett beim einlegen nicht beschädige) Update 1: Danach habe ich das Bett wieder aus den Drucker ausgebaut und aus 2mm dickem Kork 3 Schichten zur Isolierung zwischen dem Druckbett und der Aluplatte angebracht. In der ersten Lage sind die 3 Halterungen des Betts auszusparen und in der dritten die 2 Halterungen für die Fliese. Danach die Ecken wegen der Optik mit Kapton eingefasst ( ist nebenbei auch sehr gut für die Gleitfähigkeit der Fliesenhalterung) Hier ist alles wieder in den Drucker eingesetzt.

FERTIG!

Teileliste:

  • Spiegelfliesen 15x15

  • Printbed MK3

  • Aluminum Plate ca. 214x220x2mm

  • Schrauben und Muttern M3 (12x Kreuzschlitz + 12 Muttern # aus Nylon oder Metall)
  • Schrauben um das Druckbett zu Fixieren (4x M3 Rändelschraube oder Nylon Kreuzschl.)

  • Abstandshalter M3 (4x Abstandshalter +4x Muttern # aus Nylon oder Messing)
    Tip- - google "nylon m3 hex set" da ist alles drin

  • Selbstklebende Korkpads (z.b. 40mmx40mmx4mm)

  • Kork 2mm (3x 214x220mm)

  • Kabel für das Druckbett

  • Netzteil 12 - 24 V (verwende das Heizbett an den 5Ohm Anschlüssen mit 12V Netzteil ca. 60 C, mit 16V Netzteil ca. 80 C, mit 19,5V Netzteil ca 90C, 24V Netzteil noch nicht getestet)

BITTE DARAUF ACHTEN DAS DAS NETZTEIL GENUG LEISTUNG HAT!!

Es müssen 3x Halterungen für die Aluplatte gedruckt werden (Green-Tec) Es müssen 2x Halterungen für die Spiegelfliese gedruckt werden (HTPLA oder Green-Tec) Schrauben zum befestigen des MK3 Heizbetts (Rendelschrauben können auch gegen normale M3 getaucht werden)

description.text:
Goofy cat fridge magnet inspired by Kikkerland cat magnets.

I 3D printed this ornament in white PLA and painted it using acrylic paint to make it look like my friend's cat.
Print the pieces separately, insert a button magnet (10mm x 3mm) and glue the whole assembly together. The tail was separated into a different piece in order to print more easily.

Link to the magnet used: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01NGYFDOL/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

author: milasls

description.text:
This is Chumbo, a cute articulated doll in the form of a robot. Chumbo's arms and legs are printed separately from the body and then fit into the slots on the torso. I used super glue to attach the limbs, but hot glue or school glue will get the job done. Simply add glue to the last segment of the limb, then insert the limb into its proper slot. Chumbo's arms and legs will move, so it is somewhat posable. Chumbo makes a great gift for kids and adults alike, but if you print one just for yourself, that's okay. ;)
Note: I have attached files for the legs and arms to print together, or you can print each pair of limbs by itself. I would also recommend using super glue to hold the pieces together if the doll will be played with by children, because tiny hands can pull hard.

description.text:
This is a useful organization device. A watch goes on the right (cannot put in a charger for Apple Watch) , glasses (if needed) go in the middle, and a phone (made for 6+, but a 6, 7, or 7+ will work) goes on the left. The charger for the phone has a little slot at the bottom of the phone portion. The phone stand part was a design by Auggie called Auggie's iPhone 7 PLUS, 6 PLUS, or 6S PLUS cradle with sound redirector amplifier Landscape and Portrait Modes.

title: Tevo tarantula (and others) Z geared stabilizer

description.text: After my z-coupler got bent, had trouble finding a cheap solution without having to buy a new coupler. At my location it was waaaay to expensive, so i've tried a few printed solutions with little to no success. At the end I've had the idea to drive the screw by gears, having it movement constraint with a common skate bearing and the old coupler to lock it in place. Works like a charm! Note that you'll have to multiply your stepps per mm by 2 and to reverse the z axis at firmware. Any sugestions or bugs will be atended. You can see the before and the after with the orange piece before and the cat after the mod.

comments.author: povlhp

description.text: This is my first design. I got the quote from a free svg online. I designed the charm on Tinkercad.

The Menger sponge is quite difficult to print on a standard filament-based 3D printer; it's full of overhangs. Internal support won't work because it can't be removed, which leaves nice Menger sponge prints in the domain of other 3D printing technologies. On the other hand, the shape prints just great on the diagonal, as a few people have noted. That means it would be possible to print a sponge on the diagonal and glue the halves together, but that seems like cheating. If you could print the sponge standing on a corner that would be fine, but it would certainly fall over within a few layers. I tried a couple of times to use automatically generated support from different software packages, but they all insisted on trying to support the interior holes that don't need it. Then I was inspired by another design that allows you to print a seemingly unprintable object, a Moebius strip, by using external support that came as part of the original model and was broken off after printing. This design is the result, and so far it seems to work pretty well.

The print doesn't need any automatically generated support; the hollow cone at the bottom holds it well enough to keep it upright during the print. Afterwards you can leave it in place as a display stand, or break each section off by hand. I needed to do a little additional cleanup with a knife to remove the last nub of plastic on the bottom and trim the parts that had become whitened by breaking them off.  
As with the other second-order Menger sponge model I made recently, this one needed to be cleaned up by Netfabb Cloud after OpenSCAD rendered it; the STL file included in the download is the fixed version.  
I also found that Slic3r's default solid infill setting caused the very tip of the cube to be overfilled and a little wobbly, easily cleaned up afterwards but I'll be testing with a lower setting to see if that helps.

I recommend printing the body at low infill and the hook and spindle at high infill, but printing the whole lot at 25% worked well for me.

title: Impossible Dove Tail Puzzle Box
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A simple yet deceptive puzzle box.

Note: You will need some non 3D printed items to complete the box and make it functional.

-two 2mm X 10mm strong magnets
-one 10mm metal ball bearing

A slightly smaller magnet size is ok as long as it's no thicker than 2mm and strong enough to hold the ball bearing in place in any orientation.

Assembly instructions:

Glue the repulsive ends of the magnets, one inside the bottom of the round hole of each half. You will place the ball bearing into the deeper hole, slide the two halves together, then give the side the ball bearing is on a nice hard smack to make it jump to the magnet on the opposite side. At that point, the ball bearing will lock the puzzle box in place and keep it from being opened. To re-open, simply smack the opposite end to make the ball jump again. The puzzle is in that those who try to solve it won't know about this internal mechanism and will assume it's impossibly joined by the dove tails instead.

There is a secret storage/prize compartment inside of the puzzle box when opened.

Dimensions: 102mm x 70mm x 102mm (in total for both halves together)

Bonus: I've included 2 versions. A plain simple smooth version, and a very heavily ornate version. I'm not sure how easy the ornate version will be to print, but I've included it anyways.

title: 40$ SCARA Arm
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This SCARA robotic arm is suitable as a base for programming projects. Considering it costs less than $ 40, the strength it can support is not very high. The choice of materials is mainly due to the fact that I wanted to use some pieces I had in stock(For this reason I used reed sensors and 3$ stepper motors).

The top plate ("top.stl") is suitable for both a stepper and a 360 servo to handle Z movement. If you are using a servo, you also need to print the rev counter (“rev_counter.stl”) and mount an extra magnet and an extra reed sensor. If you use a stepper, you will only need an extra coupler. For convenience I recommend the second solution (also because it's simpler to program).

I decided to leave a thread hole at the end of the arm so that you can design your own modules and I hope that you will share them with the community.

I advise you to convert the steppers to bipolar function, so they will have more torque and they will work directly with the Arduino RepRap and CNC boards, to make it, follow this tutorial: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sY1Y_BJ-fTQ .

Unfortunately I did not write any demo program (I hate to programming)

If you like this model and want to see it move, write some lines and share your code please.

If you have any questions, let a comment and I will answer as soon as possible. if many people will have questions about the assembling process, I will make a video tutorial.

Material:

-3x 8mm steel bars (you can choose the length)

-1x M6 threaded bar

-6x M6 nuts

-12x M4 nuts

-2x M4 25mm screws

-9x M4 20mm screws

-34x 8mm steel balls http://www.dx.com/p/8mm-carbon-steel-slingshot-ball-silver-47-pcs-258609

-2x M3 plastic screws

title: Taz 6 elevated hexagon fan duct
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Do you like to mindlessly stare at your prints or want more accessible space to the nozzle when printing? If so, the standard Hexagon cooling fan on the Lulzbot Taz 6 is very much blocking your view, and you probably hate it.

This fan duct/mount elevates the 40mm fan upwards to give you better view of your prints.

All original mounting bolts are reused and screws directly into (thread tapped) plastic. Remove the washer on original long mounting bolt.

notable features:

  • fan is tilted upwards 10 degrees for better position
  • smooth interior air path
  • clears hot end wiring harness

revision v2 - increased duct exit opening for more airflow, rotated model to printing orientation.
revision v3 - raised duct by 2mm to minimize gap between duct and hot end mounting plate.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.35mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

This duct was designed to be printed without support material. There are some pretty steep printing angles but the print path radius should help. If you feel supports are necessary, 60-70 degree "overhang angle for support" is recommended for minimal interference.

Print in ABS, especially if your Taz is sitting in an enclosure. PLA will slightly deform from heat and the long mounting screw will need to be re-tightened over time.

No heat-set inserts needed, but you must drill and tap

To reduce cost and weight, no heat-set inserts are used on this duct. Threads can be tapped into ABS and it's more than plenty strong.

These holes are drawn to 2.4mm diameter. I recommended drilling the holes with a 3/32" (2.37mm) bit before tapping with a M3 metric tap. Use your best judgement when tapping plastic, cut slow and be careful when backing out the tap.

Some overhang cleanup might be needed with x-acto knife around the counter-sink hole for the long mounting bolt.

comments.text: was able to print and use it on my taz 5. author: robert314

description.text:
I do not have to explain the function of this item, correct?
It is after all just another filament spool holder for people burdened with R8 bearings.

Do you have a bunch of larger bearings and don't know what to do with them?
That was my case. I have 10 each R8 bearings measuring 1-1/8" OD, 1/2" ID, and 5/16" wide.
If you have 6001 metric bearings (28x12x8), these work nicely if you scale the models (94.49%)

At 1/2" diameter, I know most printers can print a functional thread. The pitch is 8TPI and clearances are build into the rolled thread pattern. This also accounts for corner rounding and blobs. I've scaled it down for 10mm diameter bearings and the thread is still quite functional. Care to try 8mm diameter for skateboard bearings? that's beyond my curiosity.

Anyway, if you build one, show us. If you have problems with it, tells us.

Printer Brand:

3D Systems

Printer:

Cube 3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200um

Infill:

no special requirements

Notes:

These are meant to be printed with consideration of the start/stop in the upper left of the build plate. All the required parts can be nested onto a 6" x 6" build plate.
For instance, you will see a start/stop relief in the nut. Reversing the nut may cause fit issues.
In general, any build draft setting should make these prints with ease.

Ready to assembly

Be sure to notice the orientation of the plastic pieces including the nuts.
If the nut is against the bearing, there is a slightly proud layer on one side.
This is meant to face the bearing. The same is true for the side rails.

Just add R8 bearings Breaks down quickly and adjusts easily.

Clean up anything that keeps the bearings from spinning freely. Check the nut orientation 1st. Some of the blobs left when the prints finishes may need to be knocked down.

This makes for a robust, low profile adjustable filament spool holder. Build plate recommended orientation.

These were printed with the upper/left as the start/stop location for the layers.

These will give you an idea of what to expect:

This model was created using PTC Creo 2.0. The custom pitch and rolled threads are a highly modified UNS based implementation. In general, I am interested in 3D printing functional threads. This one hits the mark on many levels.

description.text:
I want a more heat resistant holder for my TS100 soldering iron and had the idea, to do it with a 608ZZ ball bearing.

You need these items:

  • Best: 608ZZ full metal or full ceramic ball bearing. 608-2RS with plastic caps and plastic spacer may also work, but it could melt.
  • M3 screw 12mm or longer
  • M3 spring or normal washer
  • M3 nut
  • Best: 45mm x 55mm soldering sponge in wet state. You can also use these ones and cut it to the right size, while it is wet. Maybe these already has the right size.
  • Masking Tape

How to support me?

Do you like my things and do you want to support me? You can use these links if you want to buy something. This helps me doing more things. Thanks!

Banggood: https://goo.gl/ZXgx3A
Gearbest: https://goo.gl/FfE59f
Aliexpress: https://goo.gl/bQLi15

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

1/2 of nozzle diameter. E.g. 0.2mm layer height with 0.4mm nozzle

Infill:

30%+

Notes:

No support is needed for this thing.

Step 1: Wrap one or two layers of masking tape around the ball bearing. This is for heat isolation and is also needed to tight fit the bearing into the shell. Step 2: Put the ball bearing into to holder and put the bearing holder on the top of the soldering station base. After that, put the screw through the holes. Step 3: Put the washer and nut on the other side and tight it with a wrench and a screwdriver. The angle between the holder and the station is fixed. Step 4: Moistening the soldering sponge and put it in the shell. Final: Thats it.

Website

https://mightynozzle.com

description.text: Use your phone flashlight and put it in the top to make a bat signal on your wall! This amazing design works greatly! Have fun and leave tips;)

https://www.instructables.com/id/3D-PRINTED-CONCRETE-MOLD/

------>>ORDER 3D PRINT NOW!!!<<------

MOLD FOR CONCRETE PLANTER

PRINT IN PLA OR ABS FILAMENT

Tools

  1. Container to mix mortar

  2. Trowel or mixing stick: mix concrete

  3. Dowel or other flat-edge to screed excess mortar

  4. Air purifying mask: at least an N95 as silica exposure can damage lung tissue)

  5. Disposable gloves: to apply vegetable shorting (release agent) on the inside of the mold

Materials

  1. Mortar: DO NOT buy the bags that say "concrete" as they have some pretty big coarse aggregate that would be troublesome on some edges of the mold. Can be obtained from your local home improvement store

  2. Potable water: if you can drink it is good for mortar

  3. Vegetable shorting: this is our release agent. It is the cheapest thing that works like any other petroleum/jelly release agents

  4. Dyes or colorings (OPTIONAL): I find that if you do not use dyes or colorings + sealer, the finish is somewhat bland (ashy gray)

  5. Aerosol sealer (OPTIONAL): again, this is optional but it will give your product a nice finish that will last forever

Procedure

  1. So basically, just download both STL files (mold A is the shell and mold B is the cavity part)

  2. just follow the instructions on the packaging the mortar came in OR, you can use this rule of thumb that always works: 1 part water for every 5 parts of mortar. Print as many molds as you want and calculate the amount of water + mortar

  3. Mix: at this point add any dyes if you have any

  4. Apply "release agent" on mold

  5. Fill mold with mortar, slightly overfilling it, and screed with a dowel or other flat-edge device

  6. Wait 24 hours to cast mold

  7. At this point, apply any coloring to the planter. If you have colorings, follow manufactures recommended instructions

  8. Apply a few passes of sealer (you can use the sealers that come in a can but I find that those are troublesome and messy since they require a brush of somesorts)

title: Moto X PURE Garmin Windshield Mount

description.text:
This clip is made to work with a Garmin GPS mount with the suction cup or bean bag dashboard stand. Allows a Moto X PURE without case to be held to the windshield of your car (Garmin stand not included). Phone can be slid in from the side and is held securely. Remixed from dorsch's Moto X Garmin Windshield Mount https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:263310 .

I found dosch's mount and printed it, only to discover that it didn't fit my Moto X PURE, which is wider by about 10mm, so I modified it and the new version firs perfectly. I recommend printing the mount on its side lengthwise, as the layers will provide more strength along the axis where the clip experiences the most stress. I printed my prototype in eSun PETG to withstand the heat of my car in the summer months.

This may fit other phones and other devices, but I have no means to test this. The distance between the jaws is approximately 76mm.

Update 3/16/17: I added a small notch in the top jaw to keep it from pressing against the power and volume buttons.

title: Bear Arms and arm servo mount chassis section for Chip-E Robot

description.text:
I've always been a strong believer in robot rights, specifically that all robots have the right to Bear Arms! Simply existing as an armless biped is simply Un-bearable and i figure entering this challenge is the bear minimum i can do to correct this deficiency!

This project is a set of torso servo mounts and lovably cute Bear arms for your Chip-E robot. They are designed to insert in between the lower battery compartment and the plate that the head mounts to. They use a pair of the same servos the legs mount to, and are affixed to the chassis in the same manner. The arms are designed to screw onto the servo horns, though i do not have a set of those horns to test with, so some adjustment and or drilling of a center hole may be required. I simply imported the base STL files for the Chip-e, then extruded a set of mid sections, with an aim that they be fully 3d printable without support. Using the dimensions from the leg mount, i was able to copy that geometry and provide adequate space for a pair of servos. Future expansion potential exists for adding a 3rd rotational head servo.

Assembly:
To use these parts, print them out and then insert them into your Chip E robot using the stock hardware mount to the battery compartment, and some sort of M3 bolts to go from the center section into the upper plate and standoffs. I recommend either gluing or taping the bolts in place for that. The sevos feed in from the back. THen plug the servos in and make them do stuff. As I don't actually have one of these robots yet, I'm unsure of the details of the programming required.

New abilities and skills this modification confers:

  • Bear Hugs
  • ability to wave your hands in the air like you just don't care
  • show attendance in school
  • ask questions and or volunteer for things.
  • flip off traffic (note - flippoffarm.stl was deemed too powerful for use by mere mortal robots and has been omitted from this project)
  • show excitement on roller coasters
  • fencing and other acts of swordsmanship
  • The ability to bear arms with bear arms, which are also bare arms, unless they were bearing weapons then they would only barely be bare.
  • Theoretical ability to stir things and eat soup
  • ability to play the piano (note, talent to play the piano not included)
  • the ability to take the arms off and hide them while entering some illicit location where arms are not allowed (Arms smuggling)
  • pro football career
  • that fight move where you spin your arms around a whole bunch and hope the bad guy goes away
  • golfing!

And many more! (also the ability to later mount additional microservos and make an arm that has articulation and whatnot. )

Video describing the modification:
https://youtu.be/Af0-XlamO5s

Enjoy!

The prop guards allow for stress-free indoor flight and seem to do well in nudging the quad away from walls without loss of control.

Notes:

I post-drilled the motor and LED holes to give them a cleaner finish - not sure if it's required or not.

remixed_from.title: Prusa Mendel Adjustable Z-opto end stop

title: Vertical Adjustable Opto Z Endstop Holder

description.text:
I found it difficult to adjust my z-axis endstop precisely (fractions of a mm) once it was close. I could only find one other adjustable endstop for opto switches, however it mounted the switch horizontally, which wouldn't work with my printer, so I've modified it to mount vertically instead. I've also made it a bit more stable than the original design and it's very parametric. This is a derivative of: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15448 It also uses the awesome knurled surface library: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9095
The library is embedded into the .scad file so you won't need to download it separately.

1) Print 1x endstop arm, 1x opto block, and 2x thumbscrews. 2) Clean the holes out so the screws barely fit. This is important! The more the screws wobble in their holes, the more the entire opto switch will wobble. They will move just a bit in the holes, but once assembled it should stiffen up significantly. 3) Put a M3x25 hex bolt through each of the thumbscrews, then screw a nut down to keep the thumbscrew on the head of the bolt (I would also add a drop of threadlock to keep the nut on, nylocks are a bit too tall to use here). 4) Put a M3 nylock into the top 2 nut traps on the endstop arm. Screw the thumbscrews in, from the bottom, until the ends of bolts stick out 2mm from the top of the nylocks. 5) Put the spring on the M3x35 hex (or regular head) bolt. Depending on your spring, you might need a washer. Install an M3 nylock on the bottom of the endstop arm (between the thumbscrews) and screw the spring laden bolt through the both the opto block and arm and into the nylock, making sure the tips of the thumbscrew bolts go into the guide holes on the bottom of the opto block. 6) Turn the thumbscrews until they start to lift the opto block. 7) Install your opto switch, then install onto your rods. I put a small piece of cork sheeting behind the PCB on mine so it would sit flatter (due to the solder joints on the back). 8) Install your endstop flag. If you haven't made one yet, here's how I made mine. I took some thin plastic sheeting from the hobby store, cut a strip off, heated it, then put a 90Â° twist in the middle. After it cooled I painted it black (don't paint where you're going to glue it or sand that area afterwards, it won't hold for long if it's painted) then hot glued it the x-end-motor. 9) ??? 10) Profit!

title: Skitzo GoPro session crash absorbing 40 degree mount

description.text: New light, strong, gopro mount for the skitzo frame. I pushed the mount forward approximately 20mm and increased the angle to 40 degrees to help get the props out of view. I also designed it for max impact absorption by joining the camera seat to the baseplate with multi angled struts that flex under impact. Screws hold the front, and the back gets zip tied around the top plate. It uses a velcro strap to hold the camera in. I print it on its side with nylon filament. Nylon filament is flexible and super strong, and by printing on the side it changes the layers to a vertical stack for maximum impact strength.

title: Geeetech Prusa i3 C simple Lack case

description.text:
This is an extremly simple case for the geeetech prusa i3 acrylic series. Build of lack tables from IKEA and other mostly cheap materials. For me it was about ~45 €, without the filaments costs. But the amount of filament used is only about 200g.

Extra needs:

  • 2 IKEA Lack tables
  • 8 Magnets 5mm x 2mm (like https://www.conrad.de/de/permanent-magnet-rund-n45-137-t-grenztemperatur-max-80-c-conrad-components-505865.html)
  • 4 Planes of plexiglas 500mm x 500mm x 2mm ( like https://www.bauhaus.info/aluplatten-kunststoffplatten/plexiglas-glatt-xt-/p/20114024
  • IKEA Ledberg LED lamp
  • Tiny pieces of PCB and wire for the ledberg connector

~40 screws 3.5 x 20 or similar.

Tools needed:

  • Drill 14mm
  • Forstner drill 28mm
  • Soldering stuff

The plexiglass mounting

You need to print the lack_magnet_holder 8 times, with a resolution of at least 0.1mm and 35% and up infill

8 times lack_magnet_reverse, these are the parts put into 14mm holes in the table with a screw as counterpart to the magnets.

4 times lack_plexi_holder, these take the plexiglas at the bottom. These are put between the legs and the plate of the bottom table.

Connecting the tables

4 times a lack stackig connector like this one https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2041575

Ledberg 90° connector

2 times the ledberg connector in really high resolution with cooling enabled.

These are a little tricky. You need a little bit of a PCB and some wires. The wires a used for the male part of the connector and the PCB for the female part. Take a look at how the ledberg parts are connected and you will know what to do.

Cable routing

4 times the lack_cable_passthrough
It's probably enough to build only 2 of them and route all cables through one hole, I needed 2 holes because the extruder motor cables are two short for the position I used first.

Bottom mounting of electronics

For the power supply https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2078936
The gt2560 board is mounted with 2 of the gt2560_holder.

LCD holder

2 times needed for the LCD display, can be mounted at the bottom of the lower table.

If more information is needed use the comments to ask questions.
